Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Confirming gene expression patterns that define physiological adaptation

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oyster aquaculture has a long history in Asia that predates oyster culture in the USA and currently provides an important source of food worldwide. Historically, population growth has encouraged and necessitated the improvement of production in many locations such as in Japan; however, oyster aquaculture in less populated regions of Taiwan persists in many the same ways as it has for centuries. As oyster demand increased in the 19 & 20th centuries, cultivation of the Asian cupped oyster Crassostrea gigas expanded into North America and Western Europe. Currently, this oyster is one of the most important aquaculture species in the world when considering production volume and consumption. Due to its importance, there is increased concern to understand the oyster’s genetic structure and physiological attributes so that we may manage future demand and compensate for environmental changes related to climate change and habitat restructuring. In the past decade, the application of new genomic tools has revealed a close genetic relationship between the cupped oysters C. gigas and C. angulata (also known as the Pacific and Portuguese oysters respectively) that raise some doubts about the current taxonomic separation. Locally in Taiwan, oysters have traditionally been identified as C. gigas; however, current research indicates that oysters sampled from three locations in Taiwan should be named C. angulata and not C. gigas which is found in Japan. Sampling of a fourth location as a result of this funded research indicates that oysters are in fact C. angulata. These results indicate that C. angulata naturally occupies a geographic range that overlaps with C. gigas in temperate coastal areas, and extends into tropical coastal areas where the Pacific oyster is not naturally found.

The close genetic relationship between these two oyster species provides an interesting context to explore the physiological differences that might also separate these two species. There is current concern about how well C. gigas will do in the future due to its unexplained summer mortality. Oysters in Taiwan must survive more strenuous thermal conditions than are observed in C. gigas’ current range. This work also begins to explore the physiologically adaptive ability of C. angulata to survive thermal stress.
